question: Throughout a time interval, while the speed of a particle increases as it moves along the $x$ axis, its velocity and acceleration might be
name: q1

question: An object is shot vertically upward. While it is rising
name: q2

options.text: its velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward
its velocity and acceleration are both upward
its velocity and accoleration are both downward
its velocity and acceleration are both decreasing

question: An object starts from rest at $x = 0$ when $t = 0$ The object moves along the $x$-axis with positive velocity after $t = 0$ The instantaneous velocity $v_,$ and the average velocity $v_{x,av}$ are related by
name: q3

options.text: $v_x$ can be more than, equal to, or less that $v_{x,av}$

question: As a rocket is accelerating vertically upward at 9.8 m/s$^2$ near Earth's surface, it releases a projectile. Immediately after release the acceleration (in m/s$^2$) of the projectile is
name: q4

question: A particle is at rest. At $t=0$, it is given an acceleration that beginning with 3.0 m/s$^2$ at $t = 0$, decreases linearly to zero in 8.0 s and then remains zero. What will be the maximum speed of particle?
name: q5

question: A feather, initially at rest, is released in a vacuum 12 m above the surface of the Earth. Which of the following statments is correct?
name: q6

options.text: The maximum velocity of the feather is 9.8 m/s
The acceleration of the feather remains constant during the fall.
The acceleration of the feather increases during the fall.
The acceleration of the feather is zero.

question: An object has an acceleration of 3 m/s$^2$. The position versus time graph for this object has a slope
name: q7

question: Two particles move in a straight line towards wach other at initial velocities $v_1$ and $v_2$ and with accelerations $a_1$ and $a_2$, respectively, directed against the corresponding initial velocities. The maximum initial separation between the particles, so that they meet subsequently, is
name: q8

question: An object is moving along the $x$-axis with its position as a function of time given by $x=x(t)$. Point $O$ is at $x=0$. The object is $definitely$ moving towards $O$ when
name: q9

question: A ball is dropped from a certain height from the floor. Each time it hits the floor, it rises to half its original height. Take the vertically upward direction as the $+y$ direction and the floor as the origin of the $y$ coordinate. Which of the following graphs CANNOT represent the motion of the ball?
name: q10

question: A baseball is thrown vertically into the air. The acceleration of the ball at its highest point is
name: q11

question: An object is moving in the $x$ direction with velocity $v_x$ and $\mathrm d v_x/\mathrm dt$ is a non zero constant. If $v_x=0$ when $t=0$, then for $t > 0$, the quantity $v_x \dfrac{\mathrm d v_x}{\mathrm d t}$ is
name: q12

question: At a stop light, a truck travelling at 15 m/s passes a car as it starts from rest. The track travels at constant velocity and the car accelerates at 3 m/s² How much time (in second) does the car take to catch up to the truck?
name: q13

question: The coordinate of an object is given as a function of time by x=7t-3t², where x is in meter and t is in second. Its average velocity over the interval from t=0 to t=4s is
name: q14

question: Which one of the following statements is correct for an object released from rest near the surface of the Earth?
name: q15

options.text: The average velocity during the first second of time is 4.9 m/s
During each second the object falls 9.8 m
The object falls 9.8 m during the first second of motion
The acceleration changes by 9.8 m/s² every second

question: A car moving on a straight highway travelled the first one third of its journey at a speed of 10 km/h, the second one third at 20 km/h and the final one third at 60 km/h. The magnitude of the average velocity of the car is
name: q16

question: A heavy ball falls freely, starting from rest at t=0. If g = 10 m/s² then in the interval t=3 s to t=4 s, it travels a distance of
name: q17

question: Which of the following graphs CANNOT possibly represent the motion of a particle moving along the $x$ axis? ($x$: position, $v_x$: velocity, $v$: speed, $s$: distance, $t$: time)
name: q18

question: Each of the four particles move along the $x$ axis. Their coordinates (in m) as function of time (in s) are given by:   (i) particle 1: $x(t)=3.5 - 2.7t^3$, (ii) particle 2: $x(t)=3.5+2.7t^3$, (iii) particle 3: $x(t)=3.5+2.7t^2$, (iv) particle 4: $x(t)=3.5-3.4t-2.7t^2$. Which of these particles have constant acceleration?
name: q19

question: The acceleration of an object, starting from rest, is shown in the graph below. Other than at $t=0$, when is the velocity of the object equal to zero?
name: q20

options.text: At no other time less than or equal to 5 s
